title: Managing Humanely in the Face of Covid-19 Lockdowns
sub_head: Emerson Electric Co. Chief Executive David Farr acted in the interests of his investors, workers and customers.
body:
While politicians first dithered and then imposed ever more restrictive, often feckless lockdown measures in response to Covid-19, Emerson Electric Co. Chief Executive David Farr looked hard at how prudently to manage, not just retreat from, the problem (“You Have to Take Jumps,” Exchange, Dec. 5). Then he acted in the interests of his investors, workers and customers. Mr. Farr followed the very course of intelligent pandemic management that the Journal’s Holman W. Jenkins has been advocating since March. Accept what you must, but humanely and intelligently manage what you can.
James Connelly
Hingham, Mass.

What a difference two days makes. Mr. Farr’s very firm management style lacks any semblance of what your columnist Rachel Feintzeig espouses about empathetic leadership (”The Kinder, Gentler Performance Review,” Personal Journal, Dec. 7). Here’s to treating an employee as a whole person and not merely a worker bee.
